title: Rachelle Bond, mother of Bella Bond, pleads guilty
text:
Josh Reynolds for The Boston Globe/Pool
Rachelle Bond (left) and her attorney, Janice Bassil, reacted during the hearing in Suffolk Superior Court where Bond plead guilty to being an accessory after the fact to the murder of her 2-year-old daughter.
By Evan Allen Globe Staff February 10, 2017
The mother of Bella Bond, the toddler once known only as “Baby Doe,’’ pleaded guilty Friday to helping her ex-boyfriend dispose of her daughter’s body and will testify against him at his upcoming first-degree murder trial.
Rachelle Bond appeared in Suffolk Superior Court, where she pleaded guilty to a charge of accessory after the fact of murder. She also pleaded guilty to larceny over $250 for collecting some $1,400 in welfare benefits after her daughter’s death, which prosecutors said happened in May 2015.
Advertisement
Bond entered the plea before Superior Court Judge Janet Sanders. The judge accepted the plea.
Bond is to be sentenced to probation and time served. She has been in jail for 1 1/2 years already.

Sign up for more newsletters here Her plea agreement calls for her to testify against her then-boyfriend, Michael P. McCarthy, who is set to go on trial in Suffolk Superior Court later this year. Her sentence won’t be imposed until after his trial. McCarthy has pleaded not guilty and is being held without bail.
Bond allegedly told State Police after her arrest that McCarthy beat her daughter to death in May 2015 after he had volunteered to put the girl to sleep. Bond said she found him standing over her daughter, whose face had turned swollen and gray, the Globe has reported.
Suffolk District Attorney Daniel F. Conley’s office has alleged that McCarthy and Bond dumped the girl’s body in the waters off the South Boston waterfront using weights sometime in May 2015. Her body was found across the harbor, on Deer Island, on June 25, 2015, triggering a worldwide effort to identify her.
Advertisement
A friend alerted police in September 2015 that Rachelle Bond had confessed that her daughter had been murdered and thrown into the harbor.
Bond pleaded guilty in a calm and quiet voice. She showed little emotion except when prosecutor David Deakin described the moment she walked into her daughter’s bedroom and saw McCarthy over the little girl’s body. Bond, who hid her face behind her hair and did not look at anyone but the judge, began sniffling. Her attorney handed her a tissue.
Deakin said the state worked out the plea deal with Bond because she had cooperated with the investigation, had not participated in her daughter’s death, and planned to testify against McCarthy. That testimony, he said, was very important.
After Bond pleaded guilty, her attorney, Janice Bassil, said Bond “from the moment I met her, wanted nothing more than to see Michael McCarthy convicted for the murder of her daughter.”
“She frankly lives at this point to see Michael McCarthy convicted,” she said.
Bond lived for her daughter and had tried to provide a good life for her, Bassil said. She had no knowledge that McCarthy would kill the girl, and was threatened and coerced to stay quiet afterwards.
“I do see her as a victim in this case,” Bassil said. “She has gone through a lot and wants to see it through to the end.”
